questions.question: A bullet is fired horizontally from a height of 1.5 m at 400 m/s. At the same time, a second bullet is dropped from the same height. Which hits the ground first?
options: They both hit the ground at the same time.
It depends on the mass of the bullets.
questions.explanation: Vertical motion is independent of horizontal motion. Both start with zero vertical velocity from same height, so they hit simultaneously.

questions.question: A projectile is launched horizontally from a cliff 80 m high. How far has it fallen vertically after 2 seconds? (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
A plane flying horizontally at 50 m/s drops a package from a height of 500 m. Where will the plane be when the package hits the ground? (Neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: Plane and package have same horizontal velocity, so they remain vertically aligned throughout.

questions.question: A projectile strikes the ground with $v_x = 3\text{ m/s}$ and $v_y = 4\text{ m/s}$. What is the impact angle below the horizontal?
In the trajectory equation $y = \frac{g}{2v_x^2}x^2$, if gravity $g$ were somehow doubled, what would happen to the vertical drop $y$ for the same horizontal distance $x$?
options: The drop y would stay the same.
The drop y would be halved.

questions.question: Why does a horizontally launched projectile follow a 'half-parabola' rather than a full one?
options: Because it moves too fast to complete the curve.
Because it never moves upward from its launch height.
Because gravity only turns on halfway through the flight.
questions.explanation: Full parabola requires upward and downward motion. Horizontal launch starts at highest point, so only downward half is seen.

questions.question: Which pair of equations correctly models a horizontal launch from height $h$ with speed $v_0$, taking $t=0$ at launch and neglecting air resistance?
questions.explanation: Horizontal: constant velocity $x = v_0t$. Vertical: constant acceleration $y = h - \frac{1}{2}gt^2$.

questions.question: A stunt driver drives a car horizontally off a small cliff at 20 m/s and lands 30 m away. Neglecting air resistance, what is the height of the cliff? (Take $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
A projectile is launched horizontally from height $h$ with speed $v_0$. Which expression gives the magnitude of its velocity just before it hits the ground?
A common mistake is to use $R = v_0^2 \sin(2\theta)/g$ for the range of a horizontally launched projectile. Why is this incorrect?
options: Because $\theta$ is $90^\circ$ in a horizontal launch.
Because $v_0$ is zero in a horizontal launch.
Because $g$ is different for horizontal and angled launches.
questions.explanation: For horizontal launch, $\theta = 0^\circ$, so $\sin(0^\circ) = 0$, giving $R = 0$ incorrectly.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered horizontal projectile motion applications.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! Review the trajectory equation and velocity components at impact.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Focus on the independence of horizontal and vertical motion.
scoreMessages.0: Let's review. Study how time of flight relates to height and how range depends on both speed and height.
